snippet.textDisplay:
Hi Techmoan + others
I have scrolled through the comments but only found reference to the "Green Magnetic Viewing Film"
My work takes me to various card manufacturers where I am tasked with adjusting the "Write Heads" of various card encoding machines, and though I use the "Green Viewing Film" for a quick glance, I also use "Magnetic Viewing Spray (follow link to website "https://www.q-card.com/products/magnetic-developers/magnetic-developers/page.aspx?id=1415" for in depth testing including measurement of tape track heights to industry ISO standards. This spray on solution shows the encoding as is very easy to wipe off once used, leaving no trace on magnetic tape.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi Techmoan + others
I have scrolled through the comments but only found reference to the "Green Magnetic Viewing Film"
My work takes me to various card manufacturers where I am tasked with adjusting the "Write Heads" of various card encoding machines, and though I use the "Green Viewing Film" for a quick glance, I also use "Magnetic Viewing Spray (follow link to website "https://www.q-card.com/products/magnetic-developers/magnetic-developers/page.aspx?id=1415" for in depth testing including measurement of tape track heights to industry ISO standards. This spray on solution shows the encoding as is very easy to wipe off once used, leaving no trace on magnetic tape.

snippet.textDisplay: I recognize three of the names on that talent agency tape. snippet.textDisplay: These used to be common in mainframe computer machine rooms back in the day, where they were used for checking the alignment of the old 9-track tape drives. They also used a liquid suspension of minute iron particles in a volatile liquid called 'Visimag'. You could pour it over a portion of tape and after the liquid evaporated view the bits without a viewer.
snippet.textOriginal: These used to be common in mainframe computer machine rooms back in the day, where they were used for checking the alignment of the old 9-track tape drives. They also used a liquid suspension of minute iron particles in a volatile liquid called 'Visimag'. You could pour it over a portion of tape and after the liquid evaporated view the bits without a viewer.

snippet.textDisplay: Great video. It strikes me that in future cases where production takes longer than expected and you need a short piece to tide the viewers over, you could easily make one just using this device to look at some of the less common tape formats you've covered over the years. And I wonder if it works on floppy disks?
snippet.textOriginal: Great video. It strikes me that in future cases where production takes longer than expected and you need a short piece to tide the viewers over, you could easily make one just using this device to look at some of the less common tape formats you've covered over the years. And I wonder if it works on floppy disks?

snippet.textDisplay:
@Techmoan: You might get a clearer view of the tracks if you place a polarizing filter on top of the magnetic viewer. I can't say for sure, but it's worth a try.
ALSO: Can you get one of the modern devices and compare it to the original 3M device to see if the new one works as well? I could buy one for myself, but I'd have no way of knowing if it works as well as the 3M one you demoed.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Techmoan: You might get a clearer view of the tracks if you place a polarizing filter on top of the magnetic viewer. I can't say for sure, but it's worth a try.
ALSO: Can you get one of the modern devices and compare it to the original 3M device to see if the new one works as well? I could buy one for myself, but I'd have no way of knowing if it works as well as the 3M one you demoed.

snippet.textDisplay: my first job out of school the company used to use magnetic tape and every 6 months to a year a company came in to calibrate the tape reader, but they used fluid to eat away what I believed to be the none magnetic surface of the tape , the pattern left was the same looking marks on clear plastic tape. interesting.

snippet.textDisplay:
On the monaural tape used for voice auditions ( 6:55 ) I see Tom Bosley's voice in listed. He was best known as Richie Cunningham's father on 70's TV sitcom "Happy Days". His voice is instantly recognizable to most Americans over a certain age from all kinds of ads. I wonder what he was pitching on the audition tape....also Richard Basehart, the stentorian voiced Hollywood film and TV actor that I liked best in 1956's "Moby-Dick" where he played Ishmael. Just thought I'd toss that in if someone else hasn't already.
Playing with this thing is kind of like using Silly Putty to amuse yourself by pressing it on the Sunday funny papers and copying the cartoons. Oh my, we were so easy to amuse back then. It's a one-trick pony.
snippet.textOriginal:

I wonder what he was pitching on the audition tape....also Richard Basehart, the stentorian voiced Hollywood film and TV actor that I liked best in 1956's "Moby-Dick" where he played Ishmael. Just thought I'd toss that in if someone else hasn't already.
Playing with this thing is kind of like using Silly Putty to amuse yourself by pressing it on the Sunday funny papers and copying the cartoons. Oh my, we were so easy to amuse back then. It's a one-trick pony.

snippet.textDisplay:
That tape has the voices of many of the biggest stars of the voiceover world.

Shep Menken and several others were radio actors during the Golden Age.

Ernie Anderson was best-known as early TV horror-movie host Ghoulardi, and as the voice of ABC TV ("...on "The L-O-O-OVE Boat...").

Lennie Weinrib was best-known as the voice of HR Pufinstuf.

John Erwin was the voice of Morris the Cat in 9-Lives commercials, and the voice of He-Man.

Tom Bosley played Howard Cunningham on "Happy Days".

Hamilton Camp was a Second City alumnus, and a writer, actor, and Director.

Marvin Kaplan was a character actor, who played nerds. He was one of the gas statoon attendants in "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World".

Kenneth Mars played completely insane characters in many Mel Brooks films.

William Schallert was a very dependable supporting actor, who made many appearances in 1960s-1990s TV shows.
snippet.textOriginal:
That tape has the voices of many of the biggest stars of the voiceover world.  

Shep Menken and several others were radio actors during the Golden Age.  

Ernie Anderson was best-known as early TV horror-movie host Ghoulardi, and as the voice of ABC TV ("...on "The L-O-O-OVE Boat...").  

Lennie Weinrib was best-known as the voice of HR Pufinstuf.  

John Erwin was the voice of Morris the Cat in 9-Lives commercials, and the voice of He-Man.

Tom Bosley played Howard Cunningham on "Happy Days".

Hamilton Camp was a Second City alumnus, and a writer, actor, and Director.

Marvin Kaplan was a character actor, who played nerds.  He was one of the gas statoon attendants in "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World".

Kenneth Mars played completely insane characters in many Mel Brooks films.

William Schallert was a very dependable supporting actor, who made many appearances in 1960s-1990s TV shows.

snippet.textDisplay: You may not know that these devices were used to identify corrupted data on the reel to reel data storage devices used with mainframe computers.  One of my instructors back in the early 80's said they were able to identify the corrupted section of tape and restore the data so that it could once again be read.  The data on the tape was stored in specific patterns that were visible under the viewer.  They would literally read the data stream until they located the damage sections and then used some sort of magnetic encoder to restore the damaged patterns back to their original form.  This technique was especially useful in computer installations used by the military and is the earliest form of magnetic data recovery.
snippet.textOriginal: You may not know that these devices were used to identify corrupted data on the reel to reel data storage devices used with mainframe computers.  One of my instructors back in the early 80's said they were able to identify the corrupted section of tape and restore the data so that it could once again be read.  The data on the tape was stored in specific patterns that were visible under the viewer.  They would literally read the data stream until they located the damage sections and then used some sort of magnetic encoder to restore the damaged patterns back to their original form.  This technique was especially useful in computer installations used by the military and is the earliest form of magnetic data recovery.

snippet.textDisplay: A friend of mine I don't know anymore used iron powder on debet and pre paid telephone cards for some reason. After tapping excess powder off, overlay it with scotch tape and put that on a piece of paper, he could read whatever info on the magnetic stripes, for I don't know what reason. It was somewhat messy, so don't do this at your own home. (let your friendly neighbour kid do it)

snippet.textDisplay:
Long before Marvel started with their mid and post credit scenes I was a reader of end credits. Even so I was surprised just how many names I recognized.
Tom Bosley was Richie Cunningham's father Howard on Happy Days. Robert Brown starred in the dramedy Here Come the Brides (and guest starred on the original Star Trek episode The Alternative Factor in a dual role as dimension hopping Lazarus and his doppelganger). Hamilton Camp was a common TV guest star and movie bit player as well as cartoon voice artist. Lonny Chapman was in over 30 movies and often cast in TV police dramas. Andrew Duggan played mostly cowboys in the fifties and authority figures (like the U.S. President in 1967's In Like Flint.) throughout his career. Marvin Kaplan was best known for his role as Henry Beesmyer on the sitcom Alice in the 1970's and as the iconic voice of Choo-Choo on the cartoon Top Cat in 1961. Ken Mars is probably best known for his work in two Mel Brooks films, as the pigeon fancying ex-Nazi playwright in The Producers and the one armed German police inspector in Young Frankenstein. Percy Rodriguez was a pioneering black actor whose distinguished air made him believable as a doctor, African president or others in authority. He's another Star Trek veteran and he was perfect as Commodore Stone presiding over Kirk's "Court Martial". William Schallert was TV father to Patty Duke and our last Trek guest star. He played the excitable Federation politician in The Trouble With Tribbles. All but 97 year old Robert Brown are gone.
snippet.textOriginal:
Long before Marvel started with their mid and post credit scenes I was a reader of end credits. Even so I was surprised just how many names I recognized. 
Tom Bosley was Richie Cunningham's father Howard on Happy Days. Robert Brown starred in the dramedy Here Come the Brides (and guest starred on the original Star Trek episode The Alternative Factor in a dual role as dimension hopping Lazarus and his doppelganger). Hamilton Camp was a common TV guest star and movie bit player as well as cartoon voice artist. Lonny Chapman was in over 30 movies and often cast in TV police dramas. Andrew Duggan played mostly cowboys in the fifties and authority figures (like the U.S. President in 1967's In Like Flint.) throughout his career. Marvin Kaplan was best known for his role as Henry Beesmyer on the sitcom Alice in the 1970's and as the iconic voice of Choo-Choo on the cartoon Top Cat in 1961. Ken Mars is probably best known for his work in two Mel Brooks films, as the pigeon fancying ex-Nazi playwright in The Producers and the one armed German police inspector in Young Frankenstein. Percy Rodriguez was a pioneering black actor whose distinguished air made him believable as a doctor, African president or others in authority. He's another Star Trek veteran and he was perfect as Commodore Stone presiding over Kirk's "Court Martial". William Schallert was TV father to Patty Duke and our last Trek guest star. He played the excitable Federation politician in The Trouble With Tribbles. All but 97 year old Robert Brown are gone.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'd never seen this specific implementation. Very interesting.

Back in the early era of 2" Quad video recording, a similar technology existed for use by video editors. At that time, videotape was spliced with a razor blade and adhesive tape, much like film or 1/4" audiotape. A liquid solution (Edivue was one common brand) was brushed onto the tape, and from this, the editor could see the location of the sync pulses and the vertical interval, allowing the cut to be made precisely on the interval, and maintaining the proper distance between adjacent frames so that the machine would play smoothly across the edit point.

Personally, I don't miss those days.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'd never seen this specific implementation. Very interesting. 

Back in the early era of 2" Quad video recording, a similar technology existed for use by video editors. At that time, videotape was spliced with a razor blade and adhesive tape, much like film or 1/4" audiotape. A liquid solution (Edivue was one common brand) was brushed onto the tape, and from this, the editor could see the location of the sync pulses and the vertical interval, allowing the cut to be made precisely on the interval, and maintaining the proper distance between adjacent frames so that the machine would play smoothly across the edit point. 

Personally, I don't miss those days.
